title: Mike Vrabel named 2025 NFL Coach of the Year
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mike Vrabel wins 2025 NFL Coach of the Year for leading Patriots to Super Bowl in first year as head coach.
This is Vrabel's second Coach of the Year award, previously winning in 2021 with the Tennessee Titans.
Vrabel revitalized the Patriots after a tough 2024, instilling a team identity and guiding them to a 17-3 season.

title: Unlike Tom Brady, Tedy Bruschi has a dog in the Patriots-Seahawks fight
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tedy Bruschi openly supports the Patriots over the Seahawks due to his connection with coach Mike Vrabel.
Bruschi highlighted the Patriots' strong postseason performance, allowing the fewest points and yards per game.
Bruschi compared the current Patriots team to the 2001 team that won the franchise's first Super Bowl title.

title: Pedestrian struck by police cruiser at UMass Lowell, officials say
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A pedestrian was hit by a police cruiser outside UMass Lowell's McGauvran Center on Thursday evening.
The incident occurred around 6:30 p.m. at the intersection of Wilder and Bachelder streets.
Lowell police, with the Massachusetts State Police, are investigating the crash; the pedestrian's condition is unknown.

title: New Bedford police investigate after man goes missing, drowns in harbor
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Jason Vasquez, 51, was found drowned in New Bedford Harbor on January 31, three days after he went missing.
Vasquez was last seen on January 28, after visiting a local adult establishment, and was reported missing on January 30.
New Bedford and Massachusetts State Police are investigating the circumstances of the drowning, with no foul play confirmed yet.

title: Cambridge brewery workers plan to unionize, file for election
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lamplighter Brewing Co. employees in Cambridge file for union election with UFCW Local 1445.
The brewery has two locations at 284 Broadway and 110 North First St.
Employees seek a union to ensure worker perspectives are considered in industry changes.

title: Patriots OC Josh McDaniels named AP Assistant Coach of the Year
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Josh McDaniels named AP Assistant Coach of the Year, announced at NFL Honors ceremony in San Francisco.
Under McDaniels, Patriots improved from third-lowest to second-highest scoring offense, trailing only the Rams.
Quarterback Drake Maye credits McDaniels for his development; Maye is an MVP finalist for his standout season.

title: Patriots, Seahawks both have defensive starters missing from practice
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots linebacker Robert Spillane was limited in practice due to an ankle injury; Harold Landry III didn't practice (knee).
Seahawks rookie safety Nick Emmanwori missed practice with an ankle injury, but coach expects him to play Super Bowl LX.
Both teams are managing multiple injuries as they prepare for Super Bowl LX, with key players' participation uncertain.

title: NY man allegedly stole $325K in seafood from Worcester warehouse in 1 of several heists
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Romoy Forbes, 31, allegedly stole $325K in frozen snow crabs from a Worcester warehouse, among other heists.
Forbes is charged with conspiracy and interstate transportation of stolen goods, including designer cologne and blueberries.
If convicted, Forbes faces up to 10 years in prison and fines, as part of an FBI cargo theft investigation.

title: Loaded with trash talk and talent, the Patriotsâ€™ D-line might be the crew that wins Super Bowl LX
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots' defensive line, led by Milton Williams and Christian Barmore, has dominated opponents in the postseason.
Williams boasts 17 pressures in the playoffs, with the defense allowing 3.05 yards per carry on inside runs.
The D-line aims to disrupt Seahawks QB Sam Darnold to win Super Bowl LX, following past successes against elite QBs.

title: Man pleads guilty to Snapchat hacking targeting Northeastern students
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Kyle Svara pleaded guilty to multiple charges including identity theft and wire fraud for hacking Snapchat accounts of women.
Former Northeastern track coach Steve Waithe hired Svara to hack accounts of women he coached, involved in the same scheme.
Svara targeted over 4,500 women for Snapchat access codes, obtaining nude images from at least 59 accounts between 2020 and 2021.
